topics.title: User-centered performance and falsifying assumptions
topics.summary: Judd defines "user-centered performance" as symbolic, check-the-box research (e.g., late-stage validation) and argues research should aim to falsify assumptions rather than validate them.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Judd’s background (Meta/Facebook, Airbnb) and frames the episode around a "UX research reckoning," including what needs to change in how research is practiced and leveraged.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Teal (job search tools) and Vanta (security compliance automation).

topics.title: Airbnb research team alumni and impact
topics.summary: Lenny and Judd reflect on the notable Airbnb research team alumni who went on to lead research at major companies, highlighting the strength of the team and talent development.

topics.title: Reaction to the "UX Research reckoning" post
topics.summary: Judd describes the unexpectedly large and mixed response to his essay, including critiques that he blamed researchers and pushback on his call for more profit focus.

topics.title: Why layoffs signal a research value problem
topics.summary: Judd connects UXR layoffs to a broader systemic issue: research often isn’t positioned to drive impact, especially when teams do too much "middle-range" research that’s interesting but not actionable.

topics.title: Macro vs middle-range research explained
topics.summary: Judd clarifies macro research (strategic, market/competitive, long-term) versus middle-range research (blobular user understanding) and why the latter often fails to connect to business problems and decisions.

topics.title: Stop treating research as a service function
topics.summary: They discuss how middle-range research becomes a crutch and slows decisions when researchers are brought in late; Judd argues for embedding researchers end-to-end so they shape questions and decisions early.

topics.title: What makes a great researcher: five tools
topics.summary: Judd outlines a "Swiss army knife" researcher profile: formative/generative research, evaluative/usability, rigorous surveys, applied statistics, and technical fluency (SQL/dashboards/AI prompting).

topics.title: How to interview for multi-method strength
topics.summary: Judd recommends giving candidates open-ended problems and looking for multi-method approaches with time-scaled plans (day/week/month), plus team-level coverage of depth areas.

topics.title: Researchers must speak business and profit language
topics.summary: Judd argues UXR should explicitly operate in the overlap of user needs and business outcomes, urging researchers to learn business metrics, funnels, OKRs, and competitive context to drive impact.

topics.title: User-centered performance: validation theater and ego
topics.summary: Judd expands on performative user-centeredness (late validation studies, exec listening sessions) and emphasizes a falsification mindset—wanting to be wrong—to counter confirmation bias.

topics.title: Balancing gut intuition with System 2 rigor
topics.summary: They discuss intuition’s value and risks, recommending deliberate analytic checks and "wisdom of the crowd" via diverse perspectives—where embedded researchers strengthen decision quality.

topics.title: Shared metrics and making researchers indispensable
topics.summary: Judd argues teams should share success metrics (not separate research OKRs) and that research influence is proven when key meetings won’t happen without the researcher present.

topics.title: PM–research relationship and common PM misconceptions
topics.summary: Judd lists recurring PM tropes that frustrate researchers: "research is too slow," "I can do my own research," and "A/B test everything," explaining how good research speeds decisions and explains the "why."

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Ahrefs Webmaster Tools (free SEO and site audit tooling).

topics.title: Micro research value and the "multimillion dollar button"
topics.summary: Judd argues micro/usability research is undervalued but can be extremely high ROI and fast; he shares an Airbnb example where small CTA text changes drove major revenue impact.

topics.title: More misconceptions: Henry Ford quote and hindsight bias
topics.summary: Judd debunks the misused "faster horses" trope, clarifies researchers shouldn’t ask users what to build, and discusses post-hoc "we knew it" bias with a book recommendation on hindsight narratives.

topics.title: Research as mental-model building, not dictating solutions
topics.summary: They discuss Patrick Collison’s framing: UXR should improve teams’ mental models and guide experimentation; Judd warns against researchers overreaching into prescriptive "build this" mandates.
